newsitem.title: CHINA: Annan encouraged by China support for U.N. reform.
newsitem.headline: Annan encouraged by China support for U.N. reform.

text.p: U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Thursday said he was encouraged by Beijing's support for United Nations reforms after meetings with Chinese President Jiang Zemin and other senior leaders.
"I'm leaving encouraged that China supports the reform process," Annan told a news conference after meetings with Jiang and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen.
China was contributing to the debate on reform of the United Nations, and its leadership on the issue was felt throughout the global organisation, he said.
Annan began his first visit to Beijing as U.N. secretary-general on Wednesday saying reform was an important item on his agenda.
His discussions with Chinese leaders also touched on Hong Kong, economic development and disarmament, he said.
Annan was also scheduled to visit the Pudong economic development zone in Shanghai as well as the ancient city of Xian, U.N. officials said.
China, a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, has in the past prided itself on its good relations with U.N. leaders.
Beijing welcomed Annan's appointment last December, even though it had previously supported a second term for his predecessor Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

Chinese state media have repeatedly called for member nations to pay their dues to the United Nations -- a call mainly aimed at Washington, which has helped drive the organisation to the brink of bankruptcy by withholding contributions.

In March, Annan unveiled a 10-point plan for reforming the world body which included eliminating 1,000 U.N. jobs, merging some departments, creating a code of conduct for employees, and cutting administrative costs by a third by 2001.
The U.N.'s finances was one of the biggest issues facing the organisation, Annan said, adding that he was confident China would support his reforms.

Asked if he would continue Boutros-Ghali's policy of supporting Beijing's efforts to deny diplomatic recognition to its island arch-rival Taiwan, Annan said there was no doubt that the United Nations recognised Beijing had the only claim to speak for China.
"The U.N. has a very clear policy: it has a policy of one China," he said.
